title: Corpse in a single-room house
vignette: A body lies inside a small home with one doorway.

options.text: The doorway becomes contaminated; anything exiting there does too.
Contamination spreads only within, not through the door.

title: Tree canopy over a grave
vignette: People gather under branches that overhang a grave.

options.text: They become contaminated because the canopy forms an ohel.
Open-air branches do not transmit contamination.

title: Shared roof with partial wall
vignette: A roof extends over two rooms separated only by a partial divider. A corpse is on one side.

options.text: Both sides are contaminated under the same roof.
The divider splits the contamination; other room remains clean.

title: Covering a body with a board
vignette: To move a corpse, they slide a wooden board on top and lift it.

options.text: The board becomes a source of contamination as an ohel.
Temporary covering is not an ohel; board stays clean.

title: Loft directly above a grave
vignette: An apartment is built above an old burial plot.

options.text: Living there conveys contamination through the floor.
Separate floors block contamination from rising.

title: Coffin passing under an archway
vignette: A funeral procession walks beneath a stone arch.

options.text: Anyone beneath the arch becomes contaminated with the coffin.
Only those touching the coffin contract contamination.

title: Tent with multiple openings
vignette: A corpse lies in a tent that has two doors and a window.

options.text: All openings share contamination unless one is designated.
Only the door used for removal becomes contaminated.

title: Stacked containers over a body
vignette: Boxes are piled above a corpse resting on the ground.

options.text: Everything above becomes contaminated through the stack.
Only the lowest container directly touching is contaminated.

title: Corpse transported in a wagon
vignette: The wagon passes beneath a bridge while people stand atop it.

options.text: Those on the bridge are contaminated due to shared cover.
The bridge counts as a separate structure; they remain clean.

title: Half-covered body in a house
vignette: Part of the corpse protrudes outside the door.

options.text: Entire house and doorway are contaminated.
Only the portion inside transmits contamination.

title: Portable canopy for shade at a burial
vignette: Mourners hold a fabric canopy over themselves near the grave.

options.text: They contract contamination under the same cover.
A moving canopy does not create an ohel.

title: Entering a treehouse with a corpse below
vignette: A body lies on the ground beneath a treehouse used by children.

options.text: The contamination rises; the treehouse is contaminated.
Elevation above open air blocks transmission.

title: Doorway sealed after death
vignette: After a death in the room, one doorway is closed off with stones.

options.text: Sealing prevents contamination from leaving that opening.
Once death occurred, contamination already spread; sealing is useless.

title: Corpse in a box aboard a ship
vignette: A sealed coffin is transported on deck while passengers sleep below.

options.text: Ship's cabins remain clean if the box is sealed tightly.
Contamination pierces the box and fills the whole vessel.

title: Bone fragment under a shared roof
vignette: A tiny bone from a corpse is discovered under the eaves where neighbors gather.

options.text: Any amount of human bone conveys contamination under the roof.
Fragments smaller than a barley grain are negligible.
